title: matrices - Combining quadratic and linear matrix terms into a quadratic term
body: Given $$ C = AFA^T + A\bar{F} $$ where $A = [A_1 A_2]$ , $F = \begin{bmatrix} F_1 & F_2 \\ F_2^T & F_3 \end{bmatrix}$ , $\bar{F} = 2 \begin{bmatrix} \bar{F}_1 \\ \bar{F}_2 \end{bmatrix}$ such that $A_i \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times k}, F_i = F_i^T \in \mathbb{R}^{k \times k}, \bar{F}_i \in \mathbb{R}^{k \times n}$ and further $F_i, C = C^T \succeq 0$ . Is it possible to represent $C \succeq 0$ in the following compact-quadratic form: $$ C = A_M F_M A_M^T $$ for some $A_M$ with $F_M = F_M^T \succeq 0$ ? linear-algebra matrices Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Aug 10, 2020 at 1:16 asked Aug 9, 2020 at 20:02 P Emt 1 1 1 bronze badge $\endgroup$ 5 $\begingroup$ Why are you using F for two different matrices? $\endgroup$ kodlu ‚Äì¬† kodlu 2020-08-10 00:31:18 +00:00 Commented Aug 10, 2020 at 0:31 $\begingroup$ Do you have a requirement that you do not want to "mix" $A$ and $F$ terms? Otherwise that is trivially true; every $C \succeq 0$ can be written as $BB^T$ for some $B$. $\endgroup$ Federico Poloni ‚Äì¬† Federico Poloni 2020-08-10 07:04:08 +00:00 Commented Aug 10, 2020 at 7:04 $\begingroup$ @FedericoPoloni hi - yes, I need to keep the $A, F$ terms separate. he closest i came across was a DT Lyapunov eqn here en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation but of course I have an ùêπ¬Ø sitting in the second term so am not sure ... i just needed a way to combine the second piece into the first one so was thinking if the second-linear term could be re-written as a quadratic in ùê¥ somehow via sq. root etc but couldn't arrive at a firm concl. also, $k \leq n$. $\endgroup$ P Emt ‚Äì¬† P Emt 2020-08-10 14:51:45 +00:00 Commented Aug 10, 2020 at 14:51 $\begingroup$ Then I would suggest that you edit your requirements in the question. Your form for $C$ can only produce terms of the form $(A_M)_{ij}(F_M)_{jk}(A_M)_{lk}$, so if you want to have a term not in this form you will have to include some nonzero constants inside $A$... $\endgroup$ Federico Poloni ‚Äì¬† Federico Poloni 2020-08-10 15:43:25 +00:00 Commented Aug 10, 2020 at 15:43 $\begingroup$ thank you - i am totally open to any additions to the $A, F, \bar{F}$ matrices once I can collapse these into the quadratic expression.
